sub_topic: Probability of a certain outcome in a sports game
message_1: In a basketball game, the probability of a player making a free throw is 0.8. If the player takes 10 free throws, what is the probability that they will make exactly 7 of them?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of having exactly k successes in n trials
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (also written as nCk or "n choose k")
- n is the number of trials (in this case, 10 free throws)
- k is the number of successes (in this case, 7 successful free throws)
- p is the probability of success (in this case, 0.8)
- (1-p) is the probability of failure (in this case, 0.2)

First, we need to find C(10, 7), which is the number of ways to choose 7 successful free throws out of 10:

C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * (10-7)!)
C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * 3!)
C(10, 7) = (10 * 9 * 8) / (3 * 2 * 1)
C(10, 7) = 120

Now, we can plug the values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 7) = C(10, 7) * 0.8^7 * 0.2^3
P(X = 7) = 120 * 0.8^7 * 0.2^3
P(X = 7) = 120 * 0.2097152 * 0.008
P(X = 7) â‰ˆ 0.201326592

So, the probability of the player making exactly 7 out of 10 free throws is approximately 0.201 or 20.1%.
